packagegui.name: dnssafety
packagegui.title: DNS Safety

field.sethelp: Enables or disables the startup of DNS Safety filtering daemon at /usr/local/etc/rc.d/dsdnsd.sh script.

field.description: Choose the interfaces on which DNS Safety will be listening on for incoming requests. Default value - All Interfaces/IP Addresses.

Network port DNS Safety daemon listens for incoming queries on. Remember to create firewall rules to allow queries on this port.
Note that DNS Safety runs as non-privileged daemon user and thus cannot bind to normal port 53. It is recommended to use port 5353 instead and redirect incoming DNS requests to it as described in the tutorial.
Listen for DNS requests on TCP port too in addition to default listening for DNS requests on UDP port.

field.sethelp: Enables or disables the Arp resolve functionality of DNS Safety. Arp resolve is needed to be able to specify MAC addresses as members in the filtering policies. Default value is Disabled.

Disables ARP resolve cache (IP to MAC address mapping). It is recommended to have this value cleared. In this case Arp resolver remembers the IP to MAC mapping for 15 minutes thus making policy matching fast. You might need to disable caching to debug the incorrect workings of Arp Resolver.

field.description: Timeout (in seconds) for ARP resolve requests. Default value is 30 seconds.

Choose the interfaces on which DNS Safety will be running ARP resolve requests. It is recommended to select ONLY LAN interfaces. Note, if no interfaces are selected, ARP resolve requests are sent out on all interfaces!
Choose log level for DNS Safety daemon. Log records are stored in /opt/dnssafety/var/log/dsdnsd.log. Default and recommended value is Info.

Choose how to block the prohibited domains. Possible values are NXDOMAIN and Redirect. Default and recommended value is NXDOMAIN. If you set action to Redirect be sure to specify the redirect IPv4 and IPv6 addresses below.
IP address to redirect blocked DNS requests to. Default is 127.0.0.1.
IP address to redirect blocked DNS requests to. Default is ::1.
